selection_rationale: With many clients and higher-dimensional features, the subspace_ratio (r/d) controls communication and drift via projection size; feature_multiplier determines the dimensionality expansion, affecting optimization difficulty and per-round communication; client_frac sets the number of participating clients, balancing variance reduction against bandwidth and aggregation stability.

configs.rationale: Smaller r/d to strongly filter updates under doubled feature dimension while keeping participation modest.
Scenario baseline-like r/d with more aggressive feature expansion to test projection’s stability in higher d.
Moderate r/d to retain more signal at 2x features, probing faster convergence vs drift.
Larger feature expansion with slightly higher client participation to reduce gradient variance.
Higher r/d for more signal retention when very few clients participate per round.
Moderate projection with modest feature growth as a conservative stability–speed trade-off.
Aggressive projection (smaller r/d) for very high dimensionality to cap communication and drift.
Balanced r/d with higher participation to accelerate averaging and reduce stochasticity in large-N settings.

expected_improvement: We expect SFedAvg to achieve more stable convergence and improved test accuracy in high-dimensional, many-client settings by using moderate subspace_ratio (≈0.05–0.08), feature_multiplier in the 1.5–3.0 range, and client_frac between 0.10–0.20, thereby controlling communication while mitigating drift and variance.
